text: These are people who certainly have not proved that they are worthy of the trust that we repose in them. As far as this job is concerned, let me also indicate that when it comes to BECE, most of the decisions are taken by the Ghana Education Service. For example, the selection of supervisors and invigilators is done by the district exams officer, he explained. His comments come in the wake of a JoyNews Hotline investigation led by GH Probe’s Francisca Enchil, which uncovered disturbing levels of collusion at examination centres.
translated: [Abantu aba ndiwo osati akupatulapo chisoni chokhulupirira kuti tili nawo. Kwa cholinga cha ntchito iyi, ndiponso ndikunena kuti m'malo a BECE, maphwando ambiri amachitidwa ndi Ghana Education Service. Kwa mfano, kuchagua wasuperviza na wachipani kuli ndi ofisi ya exams ya boma, anati. Maonyo ake anabwera pamene mawu a JoyNews Hotline akupangidwa na Francisca Enchil wa GH Probe, ambayo inaphatikiza viwemi vya kukhazikika kwa mafuko ku ma centre a masulundu.]
backtranslated: [These people are not exempt from the sadness of believing that we have. For the purpose of this post, and to say that in the context of BECE, most parties are hosted by the Ghana Education Service. For example, the selection of the supervisor and the party is by the office of the state exams, he said. His comments came as the JoyNews Hotline was hosted by Francisca Enchil of GH Probe, which incorporated the benefits of the tribal settlement into the school centres.]

text: A variety of socioeconomic and cultural factors were identified as major barriers to accessing and utilizing MHCS. Over half of the women surveyed cited poverty, illiteracy, restrictions from their husbands, the distance to health facilities, and long queues as reasons for not using services. Additionally, over a third of the women pointed to cultural practices within their communities as a cause for delays in seeking care. These findings reveal that addressing maternal health in this region requires more than just improving clinical services; it also means tackling deeply rooted societal and personal challenges that women face daily.
translated: [Chifukwa chingi cha kijamii na kitamaduni chikagwiliskana kuwa vikwazo vikubwa vya kupata na kutumia MHCS. Zaidi ya nusu ya wanawake waliochunguzwa walisema umasikini, ujuzi duni wa kusoma na kuandika, vikwazo kutoka kwa waume wao, umbali wa vituo vya afya, na mizunguko ndefu kuwa sababu za kutotumia huduma. Zaidi ya hayo, zaidi ya theluthi moja ya wanawake walisema desturi za kitamaduni ndani ya jamii zao kuwa sababu ya kuchelewa kutafuta huduma. Matokeo haya yanafichua kwamba kushughulikia afya ya uzazi katika eneo hili kunahitaji zaidi ya kuboresha tu huduma za kimatibabu; pia inamaanisha kushughulikia changamoto za kijamii na za kibinafsi zinazoshikamana sana ambazo wanawake hukabiliana nazo kila siku.]
backtranslated: [A number of social and cultural factors were cited as the main barriers to accessing and using MHCS. More than half of the women surveyed cited poverty, poor literacy, barriers from their husbands, lack of access to health facilities, and long cycles as reasons for not using the services. Additionally, more than one-third of women cited cultural norms within their communities as a reason for delaying access to services. The results show that addressing reproductive health in this area requires more than just improving medical services; it also means addressing the social and personal challenges that women face on a daily basis.]

text: Despite his shortcomings, Unoka was a talented musician. He was a tall but very thin man with a slight stoop and a mournful look, which would disappear when he was drinking or playing his flute. His happiest moments came in the months after the harvest, when the village musicians would retrieve their instruments from above the fireplace. Unoka would join them, his face filled with pure joy and peace. Sometimes, other villages would invite Unoka and his band to teach them their tunes, and they would stay for several months, sharing their music.
translated: [Pa nthawi zake zilizo zina, Unoka anali mcheni wa muziki. Analikuwa mwanamume mrefu lakini mwembamba sana na miguu ya kukunja na uso wa kuhuzunika, ambao ungetoweka anapokunywa pombe au kupiga filimbi yake. Muda wake wa furaha zaidi ulikuwa miezi baada ya mavuno, wakati wanamuziki wa kijiji walipokuwa wanachukua ala zao za muziki kutoka juu ya jikoni. Unoka angewaunga, uso wake ukijaa furaha na amani. Mara nyingine, vijiji vingine vilimwita Unoka na bendi yake kufundisha nyimbo zao, na walikaa kwa miezi kadhaa, kushirikiana muziki wao.]
backtranslated: [In his other days, Unoka was a musician. He was a tall but very thin man with slouchy legs and a sad face, which would fade when he drank or played his piano. His happiest time was months after the harvest, when the musicians of the village were taking their musical instruments from the kitchen tops. Unoka would join them, his face filled with joy and peace. At times, other villages invited Unoka and his band to teach their music, and he stayed for several months, sharing their music.]

text: At the Derby Avenue RC Basic School and St. George’s Anglican Basic School in Accra, invigilators were captured openly demanding GH¢60 daily tokens, supervisors pocketed envelopes of GH¢400, and candidates were asked to contribute to an Aseda Offertory. John Kapi stressed that once WAEC provides feedback on such incidents, it is the responsibility of the Ghana Education Service (GES) to take decisive action. And so when these issues come up, once the feedback goes to them, we [WAEC] expect that they would react appropriately and ensure that the right action is taken against the people, he said.
translated: [Pa sukulu ya Derby Avenue RC Basic na St. George’s Anglican Basic ku Accra, invigilators anawonongeka wakati wakulipira tokeni za kila siku za GH¢60, supervisors anapanda envelopu za GH¢400, na wanafunzi wakulipwa kuchangia Aseda Offertory. John Kapi anasema kwamba mara WAEC ikitoa maelezo kuhusu matukio kama hayo, ni wajibu wa Ghana Education Service (GES) kuchukua hatua kali. Na kwa hivyo wakati masuala haya yanapotokea, mara maelezo yanapowapelekea, tuna [WAEC] matarajio kwamba watajibu ipasavyo na kuhakikisha kwamba hatua sahihi inachukuliwa dhidi ya watu hao, anasema.]
backtranslated: [At Derby Avenue RC Basic and St. George's Anglican Basic schools in Accra, invigilators were damaged while paying daily tokens of GH¢60, supervisors broke envelopes of GH¢400, and students were paid to contribute to the Aseda Offertory. John Kapi says that as soon as WAEC releases information about such incidents, it is the responsibility of the Ghana Education Service (GES) to take strict action. And so when these issues are raised, as soon as information is provided to them, we expect [WAEC] to respond appropriately and ensure that appropriate action is taken against these people, he says.]

text: For rural communities in Ghana, especially in the Kumbungu district, access to and use of maternal healthcare services (MHCS) remain a significant challenge. This study set out to explore the specific barriers preventing women from utilizing these services and to evaluate the quality of care provided. The research adopted a mixed-methods approach, combining both quantitative and qualitative data to get a comprehensive view of the situation. This phased design involved surveying 441 pregnant and postpartum women and conducting interviews with 20 healthcare providers. A facility checklist was also used to assess the state of clinics, including the availability of essential drugs and equipment.
translated: [Mikali ya vya kufupi kwa mizinda ya Ghana, hasa katika wilaya ya Kumbungu, kupata na kutumia huduma za afya za uzazi (MHCS) zinasalia kuwa changamoto kubwa. Utafiti huu ulianza kuchunguza vizuizi maalum vinavyozuia wanawake kutumia huduma hizi na kutathmini ubora wa huduma zinazotolewa. Utafiti huu ulitumia mbinu ya mchanganyiko, ikichanganya data ya kiasi na ubora ili kupata mtazamo mpana wa hali hiyo. Muundo huu ulihusisha kufanya utafiti kwa wanawake wajawazito na baada ya kujifungua 441 na kufanya mahojiano na watoa huduma za afya 20. Orodha ya kituo pia ilitumika kutathmini hali ya klinik, ikiwa ni pamoja na upatikanaji wa dawa muhimu na vifaa.]
backtranslated: [Due to the urbanisation of Ghana, especially in Kumbungu district, access to and use of maternity health services (MHCS) remains a major challenge. This study began by examining the specific barriers that prevent women from accessing these services and assessing the quality of services provided. This study used a hybrid approach, combining quantitative and qualitative data to obtain a broad picture of the situation. This approach involved conducting a survey of 441 pregnant and postpartum women and conducting interviews with 20 health care providers. The centre's inventory was also used to assess the clinical status, including access to essential medicines and equipment.]

text: Okonkwo was a man of great renown throughout his nine villages and even beyond, a fame built entirely on his own remarkable achievements. At just eighteen years old, he brought honor to his village by defeating Amalinze the Cat, a legendary wrestler who had been undefeated for seven years. Amalinze earned his nickname because his back never once touched the earth. The old men of the village considered Okonkwo's victory one of the fiercest fights they had ever seen.

text: Muntaka assured the committee of full logistical and secretariat support from the Ministry and urged them to partner with civil society organizations, development partners, and faith-based institutions in carrying out their work. He described the task as heavy but honorable, stressing that the people of Gbenyiri and surrounding communities were looking up to the committee as instruments of peace, reconciliation, and healing.
translated: [Muntaka wakumbuska kamati ya kupewa usaidizi kamili wa kimuundo na usaidizi wa sekretariati kutoka kwa Wizara na wakawaomba kuunganisha nguvu na mashirika ya kiraia, washirika wa maendeleo, na taasisi za kidini katika kufanya kazi yao. Akielezea kazi hiyo kama nzito lakini ya heshima, akisisitiza kwamba watu wa Gbenyiri na jamii zinazozunguka walikuwa wakimtazama kamati kama zana za amani, upatanisho, na uponyaji.]
backtranslated: [The ground reminds the committee to avoid full structural and secretarial support from the Ministry and asks them to join forces with civil society organizations, development partners, and religious institutions in carrying out their work. Describing the task as a difficult but honourable one, stressing that the people of Gbeniri and surrounding communities were looking to the committee as a platform for peace, reconciliation, and reconciliation.]

text: The study also shed light on significant facility-based challenges that compromise the quality of care. A key issue was the inadequate number of midwives, which likely contributes to the long queues women reported. Additionally, the absence of essential equipment and drugs was a major problem. For example, health service providers specifically recommended a greater number of trained midwives and the provision of critical logistics like ultrasound machines and proper delivery equipment to ensure effective and high-quality care.
translated: [Chifukwa chake, kalasi iliyesambaza mwanga kwenye changamoto za msingi za kituo ambazo zinadhoofisha ubora wa huduma. Jambo la msingi lilikuwa idadi isiyo ya kutosha ya akabbi, ambayo ina uwezekano wa kuchangia katika mizunguko ndefu ya wanawake waliripoti. Zaidi ya hayo, kutokuwepo kwa vifaa muhimu na dawa ilikuwa tatizo kubwa. Kwa mfano, watoa huduma za afya haswa walipendekeza idadi kubwa ya akabbi waliofunzwa na utengenezaji wa mbinu muhimu kama vile mashine za ultrasound na vifaa vya kutosha vya kujifungulia ili kuhakikisha huduma zenye ufanisi na ubora wa juu.]
backtranslated: [Thus, the class shed light on the basic challenges of the facility that undermined the quality of care. The primary issue was the insufficient number of akabbi, which is likely to contribute to the long cycles of women reporting. Additionally, the lack of essential equipment and medication was a major problem. For example, the healthcare provider specifically recommended the large number of trained akabbi and the development of key techniques such as ultrasound machines and sufficient self-contained equipment to ensure efficient and high-quality care.]

text: Okonkwo was an imposing figure, tall and massive with a severe expression, a result of his bushy eyebrows and wide nose. His breathing was so heavy that his family could hear it from their own houses when he slept. When he walked, his heels barely touched the ground, making him seem poised to pounce on someone—which he often did. He had a slight stammer, and in moments of anger, he would resort to his fists when words failed him. He had no patience for men who were not successful, and this sentiment stemmed from his deep-seated shame for his own father.
translated: [Okonkwo anali mtu wakubwa, mrefu na mkubwa na uso wa kutisha, chanzo chake kilikuwa kwenye mabega yake ya nywele na pua pana. Kupumua kwake kilikuwa kubwa sana kwamba familia yake ilikuwa inaweza kusikia kutoka kwenye nyumba zao wakati alipokuwa amelala. Wakati alipokuwa akitembea, viatu vyake havikuwa vikigusa ardhini, na kuifanya ionekane kama anayeyumba kwa mtu fulani—jambo ambalo mara nyingi alilifanya. Alikuwa na kikohozi kidogo, na katika nyakati za hasira, alizoea kutumia mikono yake wakati maneno yalishindwa kumfanya. Hakuna subira kwa wanaume ambao hawakuwa na mafanikio, na hisia hii ilichukua asili yake kutoka kwa aibu yake ya kina kwa ajili ya baba yake mwenyewe.]
backtranslated: [Okonkwo was a big, tall and large man with a fearsome face, his source was on his shoulders hair and a wide nose. His breathing was so deep that his family could hear it from their homes when he was sleeping. When he was walking, his shoes would not touch the ground, making it look like he was yelling at someone - a word he often did. He had a slight cough, and in times of anger, he used to use his hands when words failed to get through to him. There was no patience for men who did not have it, and this feeling originated from his deep shame for his father's failure to care for himself.]

text: The West African Examinations Council (WAEC) says officials implicated in acts of corruption during the Basic Education Certificate Examination (BECE) will be blacklisted from ever taking part in its activities again. Speaking on JoyNews’ PM Express on September 8, WAEC’s Director of Public Affairs, John Kapi, said the Council cannot continue to work with individuals who have betrayed the trust placed in them during national examinations.
translated: [Baraza la Mitihani la Afrika ya Kusini (WAEC) linasema maafisa waliohusika na vitendo vya rushwa wakati wa Mitihani ya Shahada ya Elimu ya Msingi (BECE) watapigwa marufuku kushiriki katika shughuli zake tena. Akizungumza kwenye PM Express ya JoyNews mnamo Septemba 8, Mkurugenzi wa Masuala ya Umma wa WAEC, John Kapi, alisema Baraza haliwezi kuendelea kufanya kazi na watu binafsi ambao wamesaliti imani iliyowekwa kwao wakati wa mitihani ya kitaifa.]
backtranslated: [The South African Examinations Council (WAEC) says officials involved in acts of corruption during the Basic Education Certificate Examinations (BECE) will be banned from participating in its activities again. Speaking on JoyNews' PM Express on September 8, the WAEC's Director of Public Affairs, John Kapi, said the Council cannot continue to work with individuals who have betrayed their trust during national exams.]

text: The study found that while a high percentage of women did engage with some maternal health services—87.5% attended antenatal care (ANC), 87.3% had a skilled delivery, and 84.8% had a postnatal care (PNC) visit—the frequency of care was a concern. A little over half of the participants (53.4%) had the recommended four or more ANC visits, and nearly half (46.9%) didn't register until their second trimester. These figures highlight a gap between initial access and consistent, timely utilization of services, suggesting that women may be facing obstacles that prevent them from fully engaging with the healthcare system throughout their pregnancies.
translated: [Chifundo chikaoneka kuti ngati asing'anga a m'banja akukhwimilira kwa mafunso ake a afya ya m'banja—87.5% akupita kwa mafunso a afya ya m'banja kabla ya kubabwa (ANC), 87.3% akababwa na wale wakuganiza, na 84.8% akupita kwa mafunso a afya ya m'banja baada ya kubabwa (PNC)—koma kwa mafunso a afya ya m'banja yakaoneka kuwa na wasi. Kwa zaidi ya nusu ya wachifundo (53.4%) akupita kwa mafunso a afya ya m'banja kabla ya kubabwa ang'anga a m'banja (ANC) zaidi ya mara nne, na karibu nusu (46.9%) akasanduka kwa mafunso a afya ya m'banja kabla ya kubabwa mpaka katikati ya mwezi wa pili wa kubabwa. Mafunso a afya ya m'banja yakaoneka kuwa na wasi kati ya kufika kwa mafunso a afya ya m'banja na kufikiria kwa mafunso a afya ya m'banja kwa wakati, kuchititsa kuti asing'anga a m'banja akukhwimilira kwa mafunso a afya ya m'banja kwa mwezi wote wa kubabwa.]
backtranslated: [The study found that if family physicians persisted with their family health questions87.5% went to prenatal family health questions (ANC), 87.3% went to those who were planning the birth, and 84.8% went to postnatal family health questions (PNC)but for family health questions it appeared to be negative. More than half of the participants (53.4%) went to prenatal family health questions (ANC) more than four times, and nearly half (46.9%) switched to prenatal health questions by the middle of the second month of birth. Family health questions were negative and the gap between prenatal and family health questions was large, causing the family to remain negative for the entire month of prenatal health questions.]

text: The crowd held its breath as the drums beat and the flutes sang. Amalinze was a clever opponent, but Okonkwo was just as skilled, and as slippery as a fish in water. Both men were incredibly strong, their muscles and nerves straining to the point of almost breaking. But in the end, Okonkwo emerged victorious. This monumental win was just the beginning of his legacy. Over the next twenty years, his fame spread like a wildfire, fueled by his unwavering resolve and personal triumphs.
translated: [Chalo chiliyose chiliyose chikamwa mphuno yake yakamwa na njovu, Amalinze anali mkali wa kupambana, koma Okonkwo anali mkali pia, ndipo anali mkali kama samaki m'maji. Anthu ake awiri anali a mkazi kwambiri, misuli yao na magazi yakamwa mpaka kufika kwa kupasuka. Koma m'malo mwina, Okonkwo anatulukuka mwinanso. Usanji huu uli kuwa mwanzo wa malembo ake. Kwa miaka ishumi na miwili iliyofuata, shani lake ilipitiliza kama moto, iliyochongwa na nkhaza yake ya kuthyoka na usanji wake wa kibinafsi.]
backtranslated: [Each country drank its own elephant-mouthed nose, Amalinze was fiercer than the others, but Okonkwo was fiercer too, and he was fiercer as a fish in water. His two men were very feminine, their muscles and blood were drunk to the point of bursting. But instead of one, Okonkwo emerged another. This jealousy is the beginning of his writing. For the next twelve years, his jealousy continued to rage, marked by his fiery aggression and his personal wealth.]

text: The seven-member mediation committee will be chaired by Mr. Emmanuel Habuka Bombande. Other members of the committee include Alhaji Collins Dauda (MP and chair of the Committee on Lands and Natural Resource in Parliament), Rev. Father Lazarus Annyere (Chair of Savannah Regional Peace Council), Dr. Festus Aubyn (West Africa Network for Peace-building), Sylvia Hormane Noagbesenu Esq (Ag. Director of Women, Youth, Peace and Security Institute, Kofi Annan International Peacekeeping Training Center), Prof. Ramatu Alhassan and Dr. George Amoh (Ex. Sec. NPC) who will be the secretary.
translated: [Kamati ya kupatanisha yenye wanachama saba itaongozwa na Bwana Emmanuel Habuka Bombande. Wanachama wengine wa kamati ni Alhaji Collins Dauda (MP na mwenyekiti wa Kamati ya Ardhi na Rasilimali Asilia katika Bunge), Rev. Father Lazarus Annyere (Mwenyekiti wa Baraza la Amani la Mkoa wa Savannah), Dkt. Festus Aubyn (Mtandao wa Kusimamia Amani wa Afrika Magharibi), Sylvia Hormane Noagbesenu Esq (Ag. Mkurugenzi wa Wanawake, Vijana, Amani na Usalama wa Taasisi, Kituo cha Mafunzo ya Kusimamia Amani cha Kimataifa cha Kofi Annan), Profesa Ramatu Alhassan na Dkt. George Amoh (Ex. Sec. NPC) ambaye atakuwa katibu.]
backtranslated: [The seven-member conciliation committee will be chaired by Sir Emmanuel Habuka Bombande. The other members of the committee are Alhaji Collins Dauda (MP and chairman of the Ardhi and Rasilimali Asilia Committee in Parliament), Rev. Father Lazarus Annyere (Chairman of the Savannah Provincial Peace Council), Dr. Festus Aubyn (West African Peace Corps Network), Sylvia Hormane Noagbesenu Esq (Ag. Director of the Women, Youth, Peace and Security Institute, Kofi Annan International Peace Studies Centre), Professor Ramatu Alhassan and Dr. George Amoh (Ex. NPC) who will chair the committee.]

text: To improve maternal health in the Kumbungu district, both study participants and service providers offered actionable recommendations. Women suggested focusing on public education about maternal care, enforcing free MHCS, and improving the local road network to make facilities more accessible. Providers emphasized the need for more midwives and better equipment. The study concludes that both governmental and non-governmental organizations must increase investment in maternal health and address the broader socioeconomic issues affecting women. This comprehensive approach, tackling both healthcare system deficiencies and community-level barriers, is essential for truly improving maternal health outcomes.
translated: [Kuwezesha afya ya amayi ku Kumbungu, wale wapishwa kwenye utafiti na wale wanaotoa huduma walitoa maagizo yanayoweza kutekelezwa. Wanawake walipendekeza kuzingatia elimu ya umma kuhusu huduma za afya ya amayi, kutekeleza huduma za afya ya amayi bure, na kuboresha mtandao wa barabara za ndani ili kufanya vituo vya afya kuwa karibu zaidi. Watoa huduma walisisitiza hitaji la wakunga wengi zaidi na vifaa bora zaidi. Utafiti huo unahitimisha kwamba mashirika ya serikali na yasiyo ya serikali lazima yawekeze zaidi katika afya ya amayi na kushughulikia masuala ya kiuchumi na kijamii ambayo yanawasumbua wanawake. Mbinu hii ya kina, inayoshughulikia kipengele cha mfumo wa afya na vikwazo vya kiwango cha jamii, ni muhimu kwa kweli kuboresha matokeo ya afya ya amayi.]
backtranslated: [To facilitate maternal health in Kumbungu, the study participants and service providers have issued a set of guidelines that can be implemented. Women have suggested focusing on public education about maternal health services, implementing free maternal health services, and improving the local road network to make health centers more accessible. The service provider has emphasized the need for more nurses and better facilities. The study concluded that governmental and non-governmental organizations should invest more in maternal health and address the economic and social issues that affect women. This approach, which addresses the health system's scope and community-level barriers, is indeed critical to improving maternal health outcomes.]

text: Unoka, Okonkwo's father, had passed away ten years prior. He was a man known for his laziness and carelessness, living only for the present with no thought for the future. Any money he managed to acquire—which was a rare occurrence—he would immediately spend on palm-wine, gathering his neighbors for a celebration. He believed that to see a dead man's mouth was to see the foolishness of not eating what you had in life. Unoka was also deeply in debt, owing money to nearly every one of his neighbors.
translated: [Unoka, abambo a Okonkwo, anali wafupi kwa miaka kumi iliyopita. Alikuwa mtu anayejulikana kwa kuchelewa kwake na kutojali, akiishi tu kwa sasa bila kufikiria kuhusu siku zijazo. Kila fedha anayoweza kupata—jambo ambalo halikuwa na kawaida—alitumia mara moja kwa ajili ya mvinyo wa mchikichi, akikusanya majirani zake kwa ajili ya sherehe. Aliamini kwamba kuona mdomo wa mtu aliyekufa ni kuona ujinga wa kutokula kile ulichonacho maishani. Unoka alikuwa pia ana deni kubwa, akidaiwa na watu wengi wa majirani zake.]
backtranslated: [Unoka, father of Okonkwo, was a young man ten years ago. He was a man known for his tardiness and carelessness, living only for the present without thinking about the future. Every penny he could find was a word that was unusual. He used it for a quick wine, gathering his neighbors for a party. He believed he had first seen the mouth of a dead man and saw the folly of eating what he had seen in life. Unoka also had a large debt, hated by many of his neighbors.]
